fields.description:
h3. Summary
On the Export plan to Bamboo Specs page, the "Learn More" link goes to an incorrect link

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Navigate to {{<bamboo-url/exportSpecs/plan.action?buildKey=PROJ-PLAN}}
# Click the *Learn more* link at the top of the page

h3. Expected Results
You are redirected to live documentation on exporting plans to Bamboo Specs:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Exporting+existing+plans+to+Bamboo+Specs

h3. Actual Results
You are redirected to an incorrect link:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?spaceKey=BAMBOO0601&title=Exporting+existing+plans+to+Bamboo+Specs
 
h3.Workaround
Click this link directly:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Exporting+existing+plans+to+Bamboo+Specs
fields.summary: Wrong URL for Specs "Learn More" link

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Every server maintenance with a period above approximately 10min will cause all the agents to be disconnected. This is a big pain when we have multiple agents since we have to restart them one by one back

h3. Suggested Solution
When an agent is installed, the defaults propperties affecting the reconnection are:
{noformat}
wrapper.successful_invocation_time=3
wrapper.max_failed_invocations=5 
{noformat}
^Reference: [Remote agent does not restart after server outage \- Atlassian Documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamkb/remote-agent-does-not-restart-after-server-outage-213059795.html]^
 
Please set the *wrapper.max_failed_invocations* parameter by default with a bigger value like 1440 (for 2h server downtime or even a bigger value):
{noformat}
wrapper.max_failed_invocations=1440
{noformat}

This will save the time of Bamboo admins with higher agents tiers, avoiding the need to restart the agents after server maintenance bigger than 10min.

h3. Workaround
Manually change the setting after installing the agent as described in [Remote agent does not restart after server outage \- Atlassian Documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamkb/remote-agent-does-not-restart-after-server-outage-213059795.html]
fields.summary: Increase the default time taken for the agents to reconnect in case the server is temporarily down

fields.description:
Problem Definition
Currently, we do not have a few Regions available in the enumerator of available AWS Regions

h3. Suggested Solution
Add US_EAST_2 and EU_WEST_1 to the list of available AWS regions.

h3. Workaround
Unfortunately, the only workaround would be to move your data to one of the regions available to select in the CodeDeploy Task.
fields.summary: Add new regions to AWS Plugin

fields.description: There are Repository trigger, Polling and Scheduled job already available in Bamboo. But e some projects don't use version control tool and still want to trigger job when there is a change in the directory. In that case, they won't be able to use current trigger options.  Bamboo has to check the folder at some interval and trigger a plan only if there is new file/change in the directory. It is similar to Jenkins FSTrigger plugin.I believe this trigger feature is must have and help users. Thanks.
fields.summary: Trigger feature for file change in a directory

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

When new agents are created there appears to be no mechanism to transfer dedications from one agent to another. In a case where agents are having numerous dedications, the rebuilding of agents requires manual transfer of dedications from old to new agents. This can take a lot of time.

h3. Suggested Solution
Allowing automatic transfer of agent dedications from old to new Agent.

h3. Workaround

There is currently no workaround except to do this manually.
fields.summary: Transfer Agent dedications

fields.description:
*PROBLEM STATEMENT*

Bamboo is not respecting email address change via Crowd (rename email in Crowd and then perform directory sync in Bamboo), hence old email address showing in following areas:
 * Email-id reference in administration author
 * Email-id reference in statistics list of authors
fields.summary: Old email address in administration author, notification and statistics list of authors are not changed after crowd renaming in bamboo

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Customers sometimes run into issues relating to non-ascii characters, such as non-English alphabets, symbols, etc. The solution for these customers is always to set their JVM encoding to UTF-8

h3. Suggested Solution
Set "-Dfile.encoding=utf-8 -Dsun.jnu.encoding=utf-8" in the JVM by default

h3. Workaround
Set "-Dfile.encoding=utf-8 -Dsun.jnu.encoding=utf-8" in *$BAMBOO_INSTALL_DIR/bin/setenv.sh*: {code}
JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS="-Dfile.encoding=utf-8 -Dsun.jnu.encoding=utf-8"
{code}
fields.summary: Set sun.jnu.encoding and file.encoding to UTF-8 by default

fields.description:

Some queries take over an hour to complete.

Override the expiry settings on the offending plan and select "do not expire anything for this plan".
fields.summary: Build expiry that expires only artifacts takes long time to complete

fields.description:
Bamboo is currently not offered with any standard OS packaging, and makes life difficult for admins.

The attached SRPM provides both an RPM spec file and init script for JIRA.

The atlassian-bamboo-6.1.0.tar.gz download is compressed twice for some reason - gunzip the file until the raw tar file remains, and place the raw tar file atlassian-bamboo-6.1.0.tar into the SOURCES directory. Build the final RPM by running "rpmbuild -bb atlassian-bamboo.spec".
fields.summary: [Patch] RPM support for Bamboo (v6.1.0)
Bamboo Specs tutorial fails to compile because of a renamed class

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Bamboo fails to startup after an application restart due to invalid branch keys in the BUILD table. The following errors show up inside the application log file:

{noformat:title=<BAMBOO_HOME>/logs/atlassian-bamboo.log}
2017-07-28 13:10:20,862 INFO [localhost-startStop-1] [AbstractUpgradeManager] -------------------------------------------------------------------------
2017-07-28 13:10:20,862 INFO [localhost-startStop-1] [AbstractUpgradeManager] 4410 : Make sure that all branch keys start with their master's chain key
2017-07-28 13:10:20,862 INFO [localhost-startStop-1] [AbstractUpgradeManager] -------------------------------------------------------------------------
2017-07-28 13:10:20,869 INFO [localhost-startStop-1] [AbstractUpgradeManager] Completed task 4410 with errors.
...
2017-07-28 13:10:21,012 FATAL [localhost-startStop-1] [DefaultBootstrapManager] Pre-bootstrap upgrade tasks failed
com.atlassian.upgrade.UpgradeException: Pre-bootstrap validation tests failed: [Task for build 4410 failed:, com.atlassian.bamboo.upgrade.tasks.validation.BranchKeyStartsWithMastersChainKey: There are invalid branch keys in the BUILD table: [GIT-HUB2]]
        at com.atlassian.bamboo.setup.DefaultBootstrapManager.runValidationTasks(DefaultBootstrapManager.java:482)
        at com.atlassian.bamboo.setup.DefaultBootstrapManager.performPersistenceUpgrade(DefaultBootstrapManager.java:340)
        at com.atlassian.config.bootstrap.DefaultAtlassianBootstrapManager.init(DefaultAtlassianBootstrapManager.java:77)
        at com.atlassian.bamboo.setup.BootstrapLoaderListener.contextInitialized(BootstrapLoaderListener.java:118)
        at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardContext.listenerStart(StandardContext.java:4842)
        at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardContext.startInternal(StandardContext.java:5303)
        at org.apache.catalina.util.LifecycleBase.start(LifecycleBase.java:147)
        at org.apache.catalina.core.ContainerBase$StartChild.call(ContainerBase.java:1407)
        at org.apache.catalina.core.ContainerBase$StartChild.call(ContainerBase.java:1397)
        at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run(FutureTask.java:266)
        at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1142)
        at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:617)
        at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)
{noformat}

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a plan with a few plan branches.
# Delete some of the plan branches you just created. Due to performance reasons, they're not removed immediately.
# Go to {{Bamboo administration >> Overview >> Plans >> Move plans}}.
# Move the plan you just created to a new project.
# Restart Bamboo.

The problem happens because plan branches are not immediately removed once they're set to be deleted. Once you move a plan to a new project or just rename it, the operation doesn't move plan branches marked for deletion. If then Bamboo is restarted before the plan branches get removed, that validation task will fail because it will detect orphaned plan branches.

h3. Expected Results

Bamboo should be able to start up without errors.

h3. Actual Results

Bamboo fails to startup because the validation task 4410 completed with errors.
 
h3. Notes

*Bamboo version 5.11.3 or lower*

If you're running an older version of Bamboo (e.g. 5.9.7, 5.10.3, 5.11.3), then it's more likely you are affected by [BAM-15524|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-15524] and you should upgrade to version 5.12.0.2 or higher to fix that problem, and the Workaround here may not apply to you.

*Bamboo version 5.12.0.2 or higher*

If you are running Bamboo 5.12.0.2 or higher, it's more likely that you're affected by the problem described *here* and therefore the Workaround applies to you.

h3. Workaround

# Stop Bamboo.
# Open up the *<BAMBOO_INSTALL>/atlassian-bamboo/WEB-INF/classes/upgrades.xml* file.
# Find the following entry and comment it out:
{code:xml|title=From}
<upgrade build="4410" build-min="4410" build-max="999999"
             class="com.atlassian.bamboo.upgrade.tasks.validation.BranchKeyStartsWithMastersChainKey"/>
{code}
{code:xml|title=To}
<!-- <upgrade build="4410" build-min="4410" build-max="999999"
             class="com.atlassian.bamboo.upgrade.tasks.validation.BranchKeyStartsWithMastersChainKey"/> -->
{code}
# Save the file and restart Bamboo.
# Once that's been done, Bamboo will startup and the removal job will kick in and delete the plan branches that should've been removed already.
#* You can check whether the plan branches were removed running the following SQL statement inside the Bamboo database:
{code:sql}
SELECT *
  FROM build
 WHERE build_type = 'CHAIN_BRANCH'
   AND full_key = '<PLAN_BRANCH_KEY>';
{code}
(!) Replace {{<PLAN_BRANCH_KEY>}} with one of the invalid branch keys mentioned in the error.
# Confirm the plan branches don't exist anymore i.e. removal job expired them.
# Revert the changes made to the *upgrades.xml* file and restart Bamboo one more time.
fields.summary: Bamboo fails to startup due to invalid branch keys in the BUILD table

fields.description:
h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Add the system property *-Datlassian.bamboo.build.disable=true* to the Bamboo JVM
# Configure a build plan for each of the following triggers:
** Scheduled
** Single daily build
** Remote Trigger
** Repository Polling
** Bitbucket Server repository triggered

h3. Expected Results 
No plan will be triggered according to the description "Disable building plans globally in Bamboo"


since the description of this system var is the following:
{quote}
public static final SystemProperty BUILDING_DISABLED

Disable building plans globally in Bamboo
* Default : false
* Usage:
** env : atlassian.bamboo.build.disable="true"
** java: -Datlassian.bamboo.build.disable=true
{quote}
^[BUILDING\_DISABLED - Class SystemProperty - docs.atlassian.com|https://docs.atlassian.com/atlassian-bamboo/latest/com/atlassian/bamboo/utils/SystemProperty.html?&_ga=2.136733878.76606346.1500300526-993481137.1499456836#BUILDING_DISABLED]^

h3. Actual Results
Plans with the following triggers will run:
* Scheduled
* Single daily build

Plans will:
* Remote Trigger
Will not run but will provide a false feedback to whoever tries to trigger it:
{noformat}
$ curl --user admin:passwd -H "X-Atlassian-Token:no-check" -X POST http://localhost:8085/bamboo/api/rest/updateAndBuild.action?buildKey=SUP-BSPB
<response>
    <success>A build of SUP-BSPB was triggered by remote http call.</success>
</response>
ecrmac-100676:~
$ curl --user admin:passwd -H "Content-Type: application/json" -X POST http://127.0.0.1:8085/bamboo/rest/triggers/1.0/remote/changeDetection?planKey=SUP-BSPB&skipBranches=false
ecrmac-100676:~
$ Change detection for [SUP-BSPB] and its branches has been scheduled.
{noformat}
fields.summary: -Datlassian.bamboo.build.disable=true does not disable building plans globally in Bamboo

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
In the document [Using plan branches|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/using-plan-branchese-289276872.html], the feature "Automatic Brnahc merging" needs clarification

h3. Suggested Solution
Update documentation, Explaining:
- Step by step how a normal (ideal) scenario works
- Mention how build triggers work.
- Mention limitations with manual stages.

h3. Why this is important
The feature is not clear out of the box.
fields.summary: Automatic branch merging documentation lacks of clarification

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Bamboo Capabilities can be defined in {{bamboo-capabilities.properties}} files, which require a specific syntax to map these Capabilities to Bamboo.

The keys are not always obvious to users, and there is no available guide apart from the notes section in [Configuring remote agent capabilities using bamboo-capabilities.properties|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/configuring-remote-agent-capabilities-using-bamboo-capabilities-properties-289276849.html]

h3. Suggested Solution
Could we get a list of these keys?

h3. Workaround
Many of these are available in the Bamboo database, and can be retrieved using the following SQL query:
{code:sql} select distinct KEY_IDENTIFIER from CAPABILITY;{code}
fields.summary: List of Common Capability Identifiers

fields.description: The reports are great but need to be advanced to the point that PDFs can be generated to send to 'higher ups'
fields.summary: Reports should be exported to PDF

fields.description:
I love the wallboard feature, we use it on our display screens to great effect.  Because of this I would love to see the same types of wallboards for deployments.

Naturally it needs the filtering with labels and those kinds of things that allow me to provide different wallboard displays
fields.summary: Wallboard for deployments

fields.description:
Enable Trusted keys management in Administration > Security settings
Setup applink between Bamboo and Bitbucket Server
Create new linked repository and use Bitbucket Server. It's not possible to make working configuration as in UI you see message that connection can't be established even when SSH key was added successfully. Only in debug mode you can see message that SSH host key verification failed that's why it can't save configuration.

It's regression and might be related to repository system refactoring.

h3. Workaround
Manually add Bitbucket Server SSH host key to the list of trusted keys.
fields.summary: Can'd add Bitbucket Server repository if trusted keys management is enabled

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
# When the customer has some long running branches at times (think Release, Hotfix, etc) and that feature has not met their needs for most cases on some teams/workflows and the list grows huge, there is no way to delete plan branches in bulk.

h3. Suggested Solution
Customers would like to be able to delete branch plans such as a Delete method with a JSON body on what to delete. Availability of a REST API to delete Plan branches would work.

h3. Workaround 
A dirty hack to achieve this is to constuct a script that utilises HTTP calls and perform the DELETE task.
fields.summary: REST API to Delete plan branches
Bamboo should display free diskspace for artifact store if it is located on a different filesystem

fields.summary: REST API does not expand artifacts filename

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently whenever a value is entered into a password variable, for example when running a custom build -- the password is stored in the Bamboo database and will be re-used by anyone re-executing the build without prompting to enter the password again.

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide an option to prevent the persistence of the value of password variables.
fields.summary: Provide configuration to stop the storage of values for password variables

fields.description:
h3. Problem
Some customers will try running their agents with old JAVA versions after upgrading Bamboo and the agents will fail with:
{code}
java.lang.UnsupportedClassVersionError: com/atlassian/bamboo/agent/installer/AgentInstaller : Unsupported major.minor version 52.0"
{code}

h3. Solution
Add the minimum JAVA version needed to run the agent main process into the [Supported platforms \- Atlassian Documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/supported-platforms-289276764.html] document.
fields.summary: Add a minimum JAVA required to run a remote agent in Supported Platforms document

fields.description:

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Bamboo export fails with "NullPointerException" when the "content" column of table "user_comment" is null.
We do have validation in UI which does not allow to add "null" comment but while exporting the Bamboo looks for the "content" column for the data and if the column is null then the export fails.

{noformat}

h3. Steps to reproduce:

* Add any comment to the build result.
* Go to database and update the "content" column of "user_comment" table as "null"
* Try to create an export zip from Bamboo.

h3. Suggested Solution
As we have validation in UI, we should have some constraint in the DB also, like "NOT NULL" constraint to avoid null entries.
 
h3. Workaround
Update the column "content" of table "user_comment" (where content is null) with some dummy data and then execute export zip from Bamboo.
fields.summary: Bamboo Export fails when the user_comments content is null

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently the username used for the Elastic Accessing your instance SSH / SCP commands is hardcoded to {{ec2-user}}. For customized AMIs, depending on the Distro used as a base -- this can change which means the command doesn't work as provided in the UI.

h3. Suggested Solution
Include a configuration item which can be set per image configuration for the SSH user to display.
 
h3. Workaround 
No workaround.
fields.summary: Allow configuration of the user used in SSH / SCP details for Elastic Images

fields.description:
Hi Team,

We want to extract the Bamboo deployment plan name, state, date & time, etc by using REST-API calls. I have gone through this below URL. but, we are not getting the correct date & time format. Instead, am getting some other number format, which not showing the correct date & time. Can you help us, how i can get those information by using REST Call.

URL which i am referred for REST-API : [http://myhost.com:8085/bamboo/rest/api/latest/deploy/dashboard|https://docs.atlassian.com/bamboo/REST/6.1.0/#d2e2477] [[GET|https://docs.atlassian.com/bamboo/REST/6.1.0/#d2e2478]]

[http://myhost.com:8085/bamboo/rest/api/latest/deploy/dashboard/\{projectId}|https://docs.atlassian.com/bamboo/REST/6.1.0/#d2e2481] [[GET|https://docs.atlassian.com/bamboo/REST/6.1.0/#d2e2483]]

Output which am getting:

.....

.....

.....

deploymentState: 'SUCCESS',
 lifeCycleState: 'FINISHED',
 startedDate: 1494943688865,
 queuedDate: 1494943688942,
 {color:#FF0000}*executedDate: 1494943689524,*{color}
 {color:#FF0000}*finishedDate: 1494944087726*{color},

.....

.....

.....

 

Regards,

Mani
fields.summary: extract deployment plan name, status, date information

fields.description: I was mighty surprised I had to upload some SSH keys when setting up my deployment tasks. It would be nice if we could access shared credentials for the SCP tasks and SSH tasks.
fields.summary: Make shared credentials accessible from SCP tasks and SSH tasks in deployment plans.

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When using a *non-linked* Github repository and cloning the plan, the resulting plan loses the correct credentials and builds will fail.
h3. Steps to Reproduce

(!) The GitHub repository will need to be private for the build to fail, but GitHub API calls will still fail so you can reproduce it with a public repository on the Repository UI
 # Create a Bamboo plan with a *non-linked* Github repository using password authentication
 # Clone the plan
 # Visit *Cloned plan configuration > Repositories > Github repository*
 # Hit *Load Repositories* -> Bad credentials error
 # Attempt to build the plan (if the repository is private, it'll fail to checkout)

h3. Expected Results

Correct credentials are copied to the cloned plan.
h3. Actual Results
 * Repositories UI reports the error: {{Failed to load data from GitHub.com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.GitHubAccessor$GitHubException: Bad credentials}}
 * Building the plan results in error:
{noformat}
com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.RepositoryException: : Cannot fetch branch 'refs/heads/master' from 'https://github.com/jezowen/test.git' to source directory '/var/bamboo-home-new/xml-data/build-dir/_git-repositories-cache/9517ee02b81385e7f7f2039f2f07f276195c460d'. command /usr/bin/git fetch https://jowen:********@github.com/jowen/test.git +refs/heads/master:refs/heads/master --update-head-ok failed with code 128. Working directory was [/var/bamboo-5132-home-new/xml-data/build-dir/_git-repositories-cache/9517ee02b81385e7f7f2039f2f07f276195c460d]., stderr:
remote: Invalid username or password.
fatal: Authentication failed for 'https://jowen:********@github.com/jowen/test.git/'
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.GitRepository.fetch(GitRepository.java:336)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.GitRepository.collectChangesSinceLastBuild(GitRepository.java:277)
	at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.git.GitRepository.collectChangesSinceLastBuild(GitRepository.java:233)
{noformat}

h3. Workaround
# Re-enter your credentials at: *Plan Configuration > Repositories > GitHub repository > Change password*
# Save the repository
# To prevent it from re-occuring next time the plan is cloned, you can convert it to a Linked Repository: *Plan Configuration > Repositories > GitHub repository > Convert to Linked Repository*
fields.summary: Bad credentials on cloned plan when using a non-linked Github repository

fields.description:
If the option "Save the image as a file" is selected during a docker build task the file will be saved on the disk with quotes.
This makes impossible to publish a corresponding artifact.

Bamboo version:  6.0.3 build 60004
Docker version: 17.03.1-ce
fields.summary: Save build as an image file is saved with quotes on disk

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Customers have experienced performance problems with out of the box [Bamboo AWS Wizard|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/running-bamboo-server-in-aws-858705568.html] deployments due to lack of [auto-vacuuming|https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.6/static/routine-vacuuming.html#AUTOVACUUM]

h3. Suggested Solution
Enable the Auto-vacuum daemon for PostgreSQL when deployed by the Bamboo AWS wizard.
fields.summary: Enable auto-vacuum in AWS hosted Bamboo servers by default

fields.description:
Currently Bamboo only supports the runconfig parameter of MSTest. This is deprecated since VS 2010.

Please allow users to pass additional command line parameters to unleash the users full potential.
fields.summary: MSTest Runner should support testsettings

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Some customer workflows rely on knowing the last successfully deployed version. This currently requires manual scripting to find.
h3. Suggested Solution
Add a new variable to return the last successfully deployed version
h3. Workaround
{code:sql}select VERSION_NAME 
from DEPLOYMENT_RESULT r 
join DEPLOYMENT_ENVIRONMENT e on (r.ENVIRONMENT_ID = e.ENVIRONMENT_ID)
where name = '<environment-name>' 
and deployment_state = 'Successful' 
order by started_date desc 
limit 1;{code}
fields.summary: Last Successful Deployment variable

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When a branch is deleted from Bamboo, build status is retained on Bitbucket Server. When there is a failed build associated with a branch in Bitbucket Server, Pull requests are blocked because of the merge requirement of "a minimum of 1 successful build". 

h3. Suggested Solution
 Add a DELETE call to the Remote Events sent to Bitbucket Server, which will delete references to builds and/or branches which are deleted in Bamboo.

h3. Workaround
To allow the Pull Requests to merge, an admin will need to temporarily remove that restriction from Bitbucket Server.
Alternatively, the Bitbucket Server REST API could be used to [update the build status for commits|https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/server/docs/latest/how-tos/updating-build-status-for-commits.html].
fields.summary: Send Branch deletion to Bitbucket Server and update Build details

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
If a build triggers a subprocess, such as a source code checkout, if the subprocess doesn't return a completion code, the parent build process will not terminate the subprocess. This causes a build not to fail.

h3. Suggested Solution
Fail the build and kill child processes.
Also add an error showing that the build had to be force-stopped.
fields.summary: Fail a build if subprocess fails

fields.description:
h3. Summary
If sockets are not available on Windows agents, source code checkouts will fail with a Windows socket error

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set up a Windows agent with invalid WinSocks configuration that needs to be refreshed
# Set up a build with source code checkout
# Run the build

h3. Expected Results
The build runs as expected

h3. Actual Results
The below exception is thrown in the {{atlassian-bamboo.log}} file:
{noformat}
2017-07-20 17:29:26,299 WARN [sshd-SshServer[1272c81]-nio2-thread-1] [Nio2Acceptor] Caught IOException while accepting incoming connection from /127.0.0.1:53265: An operation was attempted on something that is not a socket
java.io.IOException: An operation was attempted on something that is not a socket{noformat}

h3. Workaround
To work around this error, please reset WinSocks as follows:
# Open the Command Prompt with elevated permissions (Run as Admin)
# Run the following command at the command prompt: {{netsh winsock reset}}
# Press Enter, and restart the computer

h3. Related
Improvement request: 
* [BAM-18569 - Improved reporting when git hangs on Windows agents due to socket error|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-18569]
fields.summary: Socket failure on Windows agents

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

On Windows agents, Git checkout can fail due to a socket error. The error, coming from Windows, is
{noformat}java.io.IOException: An operation was attempted on something that is not a socket{noformat}

h3. Suggested Solution
This error is not very user friendly, so Bamboo could add to or override the error.
For example: {noformat}Sockets unavailable, please reset WinSocks by running netsh winsock reset from the command prompt{noformat}

h3. Workaround
To work around this error, please reset WinSocks as follows:
# Open the Command Prompt with elevated permissions (Run as Admin)
# Run the following command at the command prompt: {{netsh winsock reset}}
# Press Enter, and restart the computer
fields.summary: Improved reporting when git hangs on Windows agents due to socket error

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
With Bamboo using {{atlassian-user}} for user management, once the instance is configured to use JIRA or Crowd as a user directory, the local users are not available.

h3. Suggested Solution
In the absence of Embedded Crowd (BAM-11376), allow users to edit users in the local repository as well those existing in the JIRA/Crowd repository.
 
h3. Workaround
Unfortunately there is no available workaround at this time.
fields.summary: Edit Local user repository after changing to Crowd

fields.description: Audit log within database of upgrade tasks that have been run, with timestamp and status (e.g. success or failure). Ideally these log entries would be easily grouped with an identifier per upgrade attempt and show the detected version and the target version aka 'Database changelog table'
fields.summary: Audit log for upgrade tasks

fields.description: Audit log within database of upgrade tasks that have been run, with timestamp and status (e.g. success or failure). Ideally these log entries would be easily grouped with an identifier per upgrade attempt and show the detected version and the target version aka 'Database changelog table'
fields.summary: Audit log for upgrade tasks

fields.description: It is annoying having to click on the "service cog" menu to see either "Quarantine" (not quarantined) or "Resume" (quarantined)
fields.summary: Within Bamboo results when a test is quarantined please provide a visual clue

fields.description:
Currently there is no support to get  details from AssemblyInfo.cs and all AssemblyInfo.cs of all dependant project.

Support is available in TeamCity and stuffs is very easy there.
fields.summary: Support to add AssemblyInfo.cs in MSbuild

fields.description:
For each job, the "Tests" tab becomes visible as soon as the job is done. In other words all test results becomes visible as soon as all tests in a job is done.

However for a job that runs many tests it would be convenient to be able to check intermediate test results. E.g. in case many tests fail, the user can decide to abort the run.

For example, multiple parse tasks are allowed in a job. Wouldn't it be possible to update the results shown in the "Tests" tab after each parse task?
fields.summary: Real-time generated test results overview

fields.description:
When installing Bamboo through Windows installer, Windows complains that the executable comes from "Unknown Publisher" as it comes without valid digital signature, advising the user to run software from trusted publishers only:

!image-2017-07-18-11-43-05-424.png!

We should sign the installers with Atlassian certificate to avoid this security warning.  Example of running FECru installer (signed properly):

!image-2017-07-18-11-44-31-289.png!
fields.summary: Sign Windows installer package

fields.description:
Create a custom task for JIRA that can intelligently find all unit test projects within the SLN, run them, and parse them.

A unit test project has a specific projectType in the csproj, it could use this.  It could also find any projects that contain the string "unittest"

*Use Case:*

Bamboo currently supports MS Test.  It has two tasks: MS TEST Runner and MS TEST Parser.   These two tasks must be run for each unit test project.

My build project has 20+ projects, and each has a unit test project.  It is unreasonable to have 40 tasks in the build plan just for running unit tests.
fields.summary: Ability for Bamboo to run multiple unit tests in one task - JIRA

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Plans created (or updated) by Specs fail to share artifact.

h3. Environment
- Tested in Linux
- Oracle Java 1.8.0_111

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a plan with a shared artifact through Bamboo UI.
# Create a deployment project, using the previous plan and previous shared artifact.
# Export the plan to Specs. Example code used:
{noformat}
Plan rootObject = new Plan(new Project()
        .key(new BambooKey("B68"))
        .name("BSP33668"),
        "PLAN1",
        new BambooKey("PL1"))
        .stages(new Stage("Stage1")
            .jobs(new Job("JOB1",
                new BambooKey("JOB1"))
                .artifacts(new Artifact()
                    .name("Artifact1")
                    .copyPattern("*"))
                .tasks(new VcsCheckoutTask()
                    .description("Checkout Default Repository")
                    .checkoutItems(new CheckoutItem().defaultRepository())
                    .cleanCheckout(true),
              	  new MavenTask()
                    .enabled(false)
                    .goal("clean test")
                    .jdk("JDK 1.8")
                    .executableLabel("Maven 3")
                    .hasTests(true)
                )
            )
        )
        .linkedRepositories("repo-consumer");

        bambooServer.publish(rootObject);
{noformat}

h3. Expected Results
No changes at all.

h3. Actual Results
- Artifact is not shared anymore.
- Deployment project fails (see screenshot attached).
 
h3. Notes
No errors recorded in logs.

h3.Workaround
Manually sharing the artifact again.
fields.summary: Plans created (or updated) by Specs fail to share artifact.

fields.description:
h2. Summary
When Bamboo kills git command it leaves ssh process untouched. It will remain executed until JVM shutdown

h2. Details
Create plan with large repository checkout task. Use SSH key for repository authentication and native git as capability. Set command timeout for 1 minute in repository settings
Start build
See process list
{noformat}
ps axvf

java
  \-git
      \-ssh -o ...
{noformat}

Wait for 1 minute when checkout is timed out and Bamboo interrupts plan
See process list
{noformat}
ps axvf

java
  \-ssh -o ...
{noformat}

h2. Workaround
Manually kill ssh processes which are not children of git process
fields.summary: ssh process is not killed on git command timeout

fields.description:
h3. Summary

The contents of symlinks are getting removed by the clean working directory feature in Windows. This only affects Junctions. Windows also has a type of symlink just for directories, called Junctions (see *Notes* for more information). This does not affect soft links.

h3. Environment
* Bamboo 6.x building on Windows agents. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a test folder named *TestDirectory* inside the Windows server where the agent is running on.
# (!) Create a couple text files in there that can be safely removed as part of the test. Do not place important files inside this directory because they will get removed.
# Set up a *Script* task inside your build plan with the following command:
#* {code}
mklink /J "TestDirectory" "C:\Path\To\TestDirectory"
{code}
# During the build process Bamboo will create a symlink (Junction) to the *TestDirectory* inside the build working directory.
# Inside the *Job* configuration page, go to the {{Miscellaneous}} tab.
# Check the *Clean working directory after each build* box.
# Run a new build.

h3. Expected Results
The build working directory is clean after the build is finished. No errors. The symlink was successfully removed and the original directory exists with all its content.

h3. Actual Results
The build working directory is clean after the build is finished. No errors. The symlink was successfully removed and the original directory exists *BUT* all the data inside the original directory is now gone.
 
h3. Notes

(i) Junctions look and act like soft links. The key difference is that they allow you to link directories that are located on different local volumes (but still on the same computer). 

h3.Workaround
Do not use the *Clean working directory after each build* feature if you're using Junctions, instead add a new task at the end of your job and manually cleanup the build working directory using a *Script* task.
fields.summary: Contents of Junctions are getting removed by the clean working directory feature in Windows

fields.description:
Currently Bamboo specs usage lifecycle is detached from build lyfecycle - this makes it hard to implement pure CasC / PaC scenario when source code provides script / code to build itself.

It would be great to provide plan script (i.e. spec) just as we do with build tool spec (pom, gradle, ...). This, for example, allows you to refactor plans (adding / removing stages / jobs) without need to refactor / adopt older branches.

I propose the following use case:
 # Add files to VCS repository
 ** Java-based Bamboo specs
 ** pom.xml with 'generate-build-plan' profile
 ** Main project files, build scripts, ...
 # Add plan in Bamboo of new 'On-the-fly' type - this plan type has specific settings list:
 ** Project / Plan key and name
 ** Bootstrap repository (type, url, credentials, ...)
 ** Trigger(s)
 ** Plan generation strategy (in our case Maven run with specific profile)
 ** Branches settings
 ** Variables
 # When triggered plan does the following:
 ** Runs special 'bootstrap' stage / job:
 *** Makes check-out from bootstrap repository
 *** Runs strategy to generate plan being executed on-the-fly
 ** Continues build with generated plan

Here Bamboo spec doesn't have to know Bamboo URL / credentials, as well as generate project / plan coordinates - instead Bamboo takes plan generation strategy result and updates current plan with it.

AFAIU this approach will also require some special processing for 'On-the-fly' branches, as configuration will be unique for each branch. But it would be _very-very_ useful to at least have single buildNumber generation for all branches.
fields.summary: Generate plan configuration on-the-fly from VCS Bamboo Specs

fields.description:
h3. Summary
It would be nice to have the ability to change the heap size of the elastic agents running on Windows images. 

h3. Environment
An _elastic agent_ is an agent that runs in the [Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2)|http://aws.amazon.com/ec2/]. An elastic agent process runs in an [elastic instance|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/elastic+instance] of an [elastic image|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/elastic+image].
 
h3. Notes
It is currently not possible to adjust the amount of memory allocated to the elastic agents from within the Bamboo GUI. For elastic agents running on Unix-based images there's a workaround available [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMKB/OutOfMemory+Errors+in+Bamboo+elastic+agent]. However, the workaround described in that page does not work for elastic agents running on Windows.

h3. Workaround
Set the following into the instance start-up script for the image:

h6. Option 1:
Requires {{sed}} to be installed in the image which is included in our stock images but may not existing in a custom AMI.
{code}
sed -i "s/-Dimagefiles/-Dbamboo.agent.syncOnly -Dimagefiles/" C:\opt\bamboo-elastic-agent\bin\bamboo-elastic-agent.bat
sed -i 's@cd %%OLD_PWD%%@sed -i \'s/-Xmx256m/-Xmx512m/\' \%%TEMP\%%\\\\bamboo-agent-bootstrap-1.bat\n\%%TEMP\%%\\\\bamboo-agent-bootstrap-1.bat ^>^>bamboo-elastic-agent.out 2^>\^&1\ncd %%OLD_PWD%%@' C:\opt\bamboo-elastic-agent\bin\bamboo-elastic-agent.bat
{code}

h6. Option 2:
{code}setx -m _JAVA_OPTIONS "-Xms256m -Xmx512m"{code}
(!) This is a global Java variable, so any java processes that run during your builds (e.g. Gradle and Maven) will also inherit this config for their respective JVMs.
fields.summary: Ability to adjust heap size of elastic agents running on Windows

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
There is no label showing the total of tests passed in the following Bamboo pages:
# *<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-BUILD*
# *<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-BUILD/test*
# *<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-JOB-BUILD*

But we can see this information in the *<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-JOB-BUILD/test page. This behavior is not consistent. At least a label with the total test could be shown in the above-cited pages. This will help the users to understand the relationship between the total tests and the breakdown information from each new failures, Existing failures, fixed and quarantine.

h3. Suggested Solution
* Show a label with the total passed tests in green at *<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-BUILD*
* Show a label show a label with the total tests in *<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-BUILD/tests*, similar to the ones seen in *<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-JOB-BUILD/test*
* Show a summary of tests in *<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-JOB-BUILD* similar to the one we see in the main plan summary (*<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-BUILD*)

 
h3. Workaround
* Pik the number of total tests and subtract if from (New failures + Existing Failures + Quarantine/Skipped)
* *OR* go to the job tests page (*<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-BUILD/test*) on each job to check this information 

h3. Reference of screens
* *<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-BUILD*
 !DOC-T1M-76.png|thumbnail! 
* *<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-BUILD/test*
 !DOC-T1M-76_tests.png|thumbnail! 
* *<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-JOB-BUILD*
 !DOC-T1M-JOB1-76.png|thumbnail! 
* *<Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-JOB-BUILD/test*
 !DOC-T1M-JOB1-76_test.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: There is no label showing the total of tests passed in build results

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When the Bitbucket Server URL changes, users need to delete and recreate the Application link. However, there is no notification of this requirement.

h3. Suggested Solution
If Bamboo cannot access Bitbucket Server, add a notification to check the Application link URL. 
h3. Workaround
Please delete and recreate the Application link and re-save the Repository:
# Go to {{Bamboo Administration >> Overview >> Application links}}
# Delete the Bitbucket Server application link from Bamboo
# Go to {{Bitbucket Administration >> Application links}}
# Delete the Bamboo Application link from Bitbucket Server
# Recreate the Application link – this can be started from either application and you will be redirected to the other
# Re-save the Repository
(i) If the Repository is still unable to connect, you may need to delete and recreate the Repository

Note from linked ticket BAM-18273:
{panel:borderColor=blue|borderWidth=2}
If you have Plan Branches, these will need to be manually updated in the Bamboo database. To do this, please:
 # Stop Bamboo
 # Back up your Bamboo database for restore/recovery purposes
 # Run the following update query, replacing {{<old-url>}} and {{<new-url>}} as needed:
{code:sql}
update VCS_LOCATION as V
   set xml_definition_data = replace(xml_definition_data,'<old-url>','<new-url>');
{code}
 # Start Bamboo
{panel}
fields.summary: Notify users of need to recreate Application link to change Bitbucket Server URL
Pull Request hash as Bamboo variable

fields.description:
On the REST API documentation page, the {{/plan}} endpoint does not show the allowed {{expand}} variables. From the API results, these are:
{noformat}actions,stages,branches,variableContext{noformat}

I was able to confirm this on the following API docs pages: 
* https://docs.atlassian.com/bamboo/REST/6.0.3/
* https://docs.atlassian.com/bamboo/REST/5.11.1/
fields.summary: REST API Documentation is missing expand variables

fields.description:
With the current version there is no integrated SAML feature for Bamboo, we need to buy third party plugin/add-on to implement SSO.

Please provide SAML/SSO in-built feature for Bamboo.
fields.summary: Provide SAML/SSO Implementation for Bamboo

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently we don't have a way to download the Bamboo Specs HLL representation of a Plan without copying and pasting the generated output.

h3. Suggested Solution
Add a downloadable file to retrieve the Specs output.

h3. Workaround
Please copy and paste the generated Bamboo Specs code into a file.
fields.summary: Download Bamboo Specs plan representation

fields.description:
h3. Summary
After a plan that produces a Shared Artifact is deleted, any plan that consumes that artifact fails. Although this is expected, disabling the Artifact Download task should allow the plan to run.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a Plan *Throwaway Artifact* that produces a Shared Artifact
# Create a second Plan *Artifact Test* that consumes the Shared Artifact
# Run the *Throwaway Artifact* Plan to produce the artifact
# Run *Artifact Test* to successfully consume the Artifact
# Disable the *Artifact Download task* in *Artifact Test*
# Delete the *Throwaway Artifact* Plan
# Re-run the *Artifact Test* Plan

h3. Expected Results
Because the Artifact Download task is disabled, it should not affect the execution of the build plan.

h3. Actual Results
The build does not start and the following exception is thrown in the {{atlassian-bamboo.log}} file and Build Result Summary page:
{noformat}
2017-07-07 14:04:27,355 WARN [5-DelayedChangeDetectionThread:pool-11-thread-3] [ArtifactDownloaderRuntimeDataProvider] Unable to find plan [TEST-TA]
2017-07-07 14:04:27,355 ERROR [5-DelayedChangeDetectionThread:pool-11-thread-3] [ChainPluginSupportHelper] Task context data provider failed:java.lang.IllegalStateException: Unable to find plan [TEST-T
A]
2017-07-07 14:04:27,356 INFO [5-DelayedChangeDetectionThread:pool-11-thread-3] [DefaultErrorHandler] Recording an error: com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.bamboo-artifact-downloader-plugin:artifactdownloade
rtask : TEST-AT-JOB1 : Unable to find plan [TEST-TA]
2017-07-07 14:04:27,356 ERROR [5-DelayedChangeDetectionThread:pool-11-thread-3] [ChainExecutionManagerImpl] Plan 'TEST-AT-2' started but a fatal error occurred
java.lang.RuntimeException: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Unable to find plan [TEST-TA]
...
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Unable to find plan [TEST-TA]
...
{noformat}
 

h3.Workaround
Delete any Artifact Download tasks which consumes an Artifact produced by a deleted Plan.
fields.summary: Disabled Artifact Downloader task still checks for existence of artifact

fields.description:
In order for Bamboo Specs to be used in an enterprise environment, it is critical to be able to determine when a plan configuration has been updated via Specs.  Currently there is no audit event generated to show this occurs.  This is a potential security risk.

Since audit log events do not appear to be generated for the addition of stages/tasks, this opens up a possibility where a bad actor can add and push malicious tasks via Specs and not leave any trail of the activity in the Bamboo plan audit log.
fields.summary: Audit log events for Bamboo Specs publishing
Bamboo Specs: Uploading linked repository where's a name clash gives crypting message

fields.description:
In BAM-18351, a flag to toggle branch cleanup for a particular branch was suggested as a new /plan/.../branch endpoint.  This would allow admins to programmatically toggle the cleanup status of plan branches.  However, it would also be beneficial to be able to fine-tune the plan branch deletion policy at creation time rather than have to go back after creation and push an API call.

In our use case, we have procedures that roll through a set of repositories and generate release branches.  This works well; however, because we cannot fine-tune branch expiration based on a regular expression, we need to go into each of _n_ release branches and manually uncheck the cleanup checkbox.  We not only have to do this for releases but for certain long-running (but potentially idle) branches, which should remain in place until merged.

The ideal UI change would would allow for a regular expression to control expiration.  The current UI looks like:
 * Delete plan branch
 ** (/) After branch was deleted from repository
 *** # days
 ** (/) After branch inactivity in repository
 *** # days

 

A more granular solution would look more like:
 * Delete plan branch
 ** (/) *Only delete plan branches matching the expression:*
 *** *(regex box)*
 ** (/) After branch was deleted from repository
 *** # days
 ** (/) After branch inactivity in repository
 *** # days
fields.summary: Allow regular expression control of plan branch deletion.

fields.description:
In -BAM-17224-, a flag to toggle branch cleanup for a particular branch was added to the /plan/.../branch endpoint.  This helps out quite a bit with the creation of branches, but a more practical use case is managing the cleanup status of branches which have already been detected and created, e.g. release branches.

In our use case, we have procedures that roll through a set of repositories and generate release branches.  This works well; however, because we cannot fine-tune branch expiration based on a regular expression, we need to go into each of _n_ release branches and manually uncheck the cleanup checkbox.  We not only have to do this for releases but for certain long-running (but potentially idle) branches, which should remain in place until merged.

 

There is already a /plan/<key>/enable endpoint, so it seems like a /plan/<key>enableCleanup endpoint would be simple and useful to implement as well.
fields.summary: Create REST endpoint to toggle branch cleanup option

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently the below message is logged when Bamboo can't place a spot instance request due to [spot instance limits|http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/using-spot-limits.html#spot-limits-general]:
{code}
2017-06-16 09:34:44,066 WARN [elastic-pool-4-thread-2] [AwsSpotInstanceLauncher] Unable to place a spot instance request, proceeding with regular instance order
{code}

h3. Suggested Solution
Log a reference to the reason the spot instance request couldn't be placed and had to fallback to a regular instance order. E.g. Include the AWS failure reason "Max spot instance count exceeded"
fields.summary: Improve the warning logged when a spot instance request can't be placed due to spot instance limits in Bamboo

At the same time since version 6.0 Bamboo sends INPROGRESS status to Bitbucket Server. 

It should send INPROGRESS status to Bitbucket Cloud as well.
fields.summary: Send INPROGRESS status for Bitbucket Cloud

fields.description:
h3. Summary
If a Trigger is enabled, Change Detection runs after a build and tries to trigger a new build with any changes (BAM-18497). With customized builds ({{Run >> Run Customized}}), users have the option to run off of custom commit hashes, which may be on different branches. In these cases, Bamboo will not be able to download the changes and run the build. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Add a branch {{more_tests}} to a build
# Configure a variable for the branch name ({{BRANCH_NAME}})
# Add a trigger on the repository
# Do not merge {{more_tests}} to master
# Run a custom build using the {{more_tests}} branch

h3. Expected Results
Build runs as expected

h3. Actual Results
* A build ran as expected using the latest changeset on {{more_tests}}; but
* Immediately after the build, change detection finds the delta between the revision used in the custom build and the latest revision on the master branch and triggers a new build

The following appears in the Commits tab:
{noformat}[unknown]
Bamboo was unable to extract changes between revision <more_tests_commit_hash> and <master_commit_hash>.{noformat}
 
h3.Workaround
Remove any Triggers from the build
fields.summary: Do not run Change Detection after customized run

fields.description:
I import a instance from a bamboo server to another test bamboo server.

the plan and history can show normally, but when I try to view or download the log, it report an error :

nternal server error
Go to...

    Site homepage

A system error has occurred - our apologies!

Please create a problem report on our support system at http://support.atlassian.com with the following information:

    a description of your problem and what you were doing at the time it occurred
    cut & paste the error and system information found below
    attach the atlassian-bamboo.log log file found in your application home. 

We will respond as promptly as possible.
Thank you!

Version: 5.14.3.1
Build: 51416

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Artifacts sharing does not work with using S3 and Remote handler

Plan A
 Artifact Handlers: Bamboo remote handler
Plan B
 Artifact Handlers: Amazon S3

Plan B uses Plan A artifacts for a build.
But like a this case both plans do not use same location, the build task fails.


h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set Plan A Artifact Handlers to Bamboo remote handler
# Set Plan B Artifact Handlers to Amazon S3
# Perform build

h3. Expected Results
Succeeded the build.

h3. Actual Results
Fail the build.
fields.summary: Artifacts sharing does not work with using Amazon S3 and Remote handler

fields.description:
As a normal plan user (All permissions except admin) I want to link and create JIRA issues.

At the moment this is only allowed with admin permission on the plan.
fields.summary: JIRA Issue Linking As Non-Admin

fields.summary: java.util.NoSuchElementException: No value present when trying to import job which was deleted

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
The greatest load by far that CI systems put on SCM systems is inefficiently configured polling for changes. As an admin, I want to know the load my plan configurations are putting on my source control management system(s) so I can identify inefficient configuration and correct it.

h3. Suggested Solution
Add a UI section that surfaces information about which plans are configured to poll for changes, and at what frequency. This should also show the repositories that are linked to that build plan. Optionally this could also include other SCM stats, such as average/daily fetches / clones, whether shallow clones are enabled, etc; and should show an overall picture of the activity of the instance (e.g. "Your Bamboo server is polling various SCM systems for changes a total of 1,000,000 times per day")

This information should also be included in support zips, to enable Atlassian Support to analyse this info.

h3. Workaround
Various manual database queries can be run to gather some of this information,
fields.summary: SCM analytics

fields.description:
h3. Summary
* Git version (v1.8) stated in documentation (https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Supported+platforms) is inaccurate, causing issues in Bamboo server.

h3. Overview
When running *{color:blue}Automatic branch merging{color}* against a Git repository Bamboo:
* create a directory in {color:blue}<bamboo-home>/xml-data/build-dir/serverSide/{color}{color:red}PROJ-PLAN0-123{color}{color:blue}/mergeWorkspace{color} to be used by the merge event
* run a command that uses {color:blue}-c{color} parameter
{noformat}
git clone <bamboo-home>/xml-data/build-dir/_git-repositories-cache/b1a5506f772601076f7b53ae0c0dcb2f697cafc1 --shared --no-checkout '-c filter.lfs.smudge=' '-c filter.lfs.required=false' <bamboo-home>/xml-data/build-dir/serverSide/PROJ-PLAN0-123/mergeWorkspace
{noformat}

h3. Issue
* Git version below 1.8.1.5 does not have {color:blue}-c{color} parameter, in which causes failure in Bamboo
{noformat}
2017-02-15 10:57:15,271 WARN [5-DelayedChangeDetectionThread:pool-11-thread-5] [ChainExecutionManagerImpl] Merge command error: fatal: Not a git repository (or any of the parent directories): .git
2017-02-15 10:57:15,271 WARN [5-DelayedChangeDetectionThread:pool-11-thread-5] [ChainExecutionManagerImpl] Unable to merge PROJ-PLAN0-123 merge result: MergeResultSummaryImpl
{integrationStrategy='GATE_KEEPER', mergeState='FAILED', pushState='TO_BE_ATTEMPTED', failureReason='Merge command error: fatal: Not a git repository (or any of the parent directories): .git', integrationBranchVcsKey='93623c155d66e0fa117bf10202ad9ef857f31990', mergeResultVcsKey='null', integrationRepositoryId=176390237, integrationRepositoryBranchName='foo', branchTargetVcsKey='0b0cb1c487fdb62d198b3bb9d9e54c42dd39cfe5', branchName='bar'}
2017-02-15 10:57:15,272 ERROR [5-DelayedChangeDetectionThread:pool-11-thread-5] [ChainExecutionManagerImpl] Failed to merge for plan-result: PROJ-PLAN0-123. Merge command error: fatal: Not a git repository (or any of the parent directories): .git
{noformat}

h3. Suggestion
* Update documentation https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Supported+platforms, replacing Git version 1.8 with 1.8.1.5 or above (_*in the Bamboo server*_)
* Update documentation https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Using+plan+branches, stating {color:blue}Limitations with plan branches >> Auto branch merging{color} requires Git version 1.8.1.5 or above as capability (_*in the Bamboo server*_).
fields.summary: Documentation - Update Git version supported

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently, Bamboo Activity Reports [Viewing build statistics for all users|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/viewing-build-statistics-for-all-users-289276966.html] gives us an overview by user. There has to be a possibility to list daily reporting of plan executions like number of build, etc, with a possibility to see hourly based.

For example:
...
09:00 --> 10:00 150 plan executions
10:00 --> 11:00 50 plan executions
11:00 --> 12:00 75 plan executions
12:00 --> 13:00 25 plan executions
...
fields.summary: Possibility to get stats on the usage of bamboo server process during a period

fields.description:
h3. Summary
The docker daemon doesn't start successfully on Elastic Agents using a EBS-only instance type (such as T2, M4) with the Ubuntu Stock Image. This causes the first build of any build using a docker task to fail. The first docker command will hang for about a minute before timing out with an error. The docker daemon appears to listen after the first docker command fails and works thereafter.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Start an Elastic Agent with the Ubuntu Stock Image and configured to use a T2 instance type.
# Start a build using a docker task on that agent. E.g. Docker pull to fetch an image from a private repository.

h3. Expected Results
Build succeeds

h3. Actual Results
Build hangs (HungBuildKiller may step in) and eventually fails:
{noformat}
build	14-Jun-2017 22:11:16	Not logged in to https://index.docker.io/v1/
error	14-Jun-2017 22:11:16	Error occurred while running Task 'Pull Image(1)' of type com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.bamboo-docker-plugin:task.docker.cli.
error	14-Jun-2017 22:11:16	com.atlassian.bamboo.task.TaskException: Failed to execute task
error	14-Jun-2017 22:11:16		at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.docker.service.PullService.execute(PullService.java:41)
error	14-Jun-2017 22:11:16		at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.docker.tasks.cli.DockerCliTask.execute(DockerCliTask.java:60)

error	14-Jun-2017 22:11:16		at com.atlassian.bamboo.v2.build.agent.DefaultBuildAgent.build(DefaultBuildAgent.java:216)

error	14-Jun-2017 22:11:16		at com.atlassian.bamboo.v2.build.agent.BuildAgentControllerImpl$1.call(BuildAgentControllerImpl.java:130)

error	14-Jun-2017 22:11:16		at com.atlassian.bamboo.v2.build.agent.BuildAgentControllerImpl.waitAndPerformBuild(BuildAgentControllerImpl.java:129)

error	14-Jun-2017 22:11:16		at com.atlassian.bamboo.security.ImpersonationHelper$1.run(ImpersonationHelper.java:52)
error	14-Jun-2017 22:11:16		at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)

Add the below command to your *Instance startup script* at *Bamboo Administration > Overview > Image Configurations > Edit elastic image configuration*:

service docker restart
{code}

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently, in {{<bamboo-install>/atlassian-bamboo/WEB-INF/classes/bamboo-init.properties}}, the {{bamboo.home}} example points to a Windows file path {{C:\bamboo\bamboo-home}}
h3. Suggested Solution
Have the example either blank or match the format required for its (most common) OS.
* Tar.gz: Linux/Mac OS X (Unix)
* Zip: Windows
* EXE: Windows
h3. Workaround
There is no workaround, it will need to be manually edited.
fields.summary: Example bamboo.home should match the Operating System standard

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Risks of migration and upgrade failure due to property (e.g {color:blue}<serverId />{color} and {color:blue}<serverKey />{color}) being stored in {color:blue}<bamboo-home>/bamboo.cfg.xml{color} filesystem instead of database.

h3. Suggestion 
Some properties (e.g {color:blue}<serverId />{color} and {color:blue}<serverKey />{color}) in {color:blue}<bamboo-home>/bamboo.cfg.xml{color} should be moved/stored in the database, minimising the risks of  unsuccessful Bamboo's migration or upgrade.
fields.summary: Move serverId and serverKey from bamboo.cfg.xml to a database property
Move buildNumber from bamboo.cfg.xml to a database property

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When saving a Bitbucket Server repository in Bamboo, the error message _New access key is required but could not be added to Bitbucket Server_ is not always indicative of the actual problem.

For example, this can occur when the SSH key was successfully added via the Application Link to the Bitbucket Server repository however one of the below issues is causing a failure when testing the connection:
# Git SSH test failed to make a connection.
# Git executable couldn't be found / launched.
# Custom Git SSH executable couldn't be found / launched.

h3. Suggested Solution
Communicate the underlying issue or exception to the UI when the error occurs.

h3. Notes
Knowledge-base article with known causes and resolutions:
* [New access key is required but could not be added to Bitbucket Server|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamkb/new-access-key-is-required-but-could-not-be-added-to-bitbucket-server-808616180.html]
fields.summary: Improve error communication for "New access key is required but could not be added to Bitbucket Server" in Bamboo

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Bamboo test results show unexpected results when testcase classpath is null

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a build that parses the following test file
{noformat}
<testsuite errors="0" failures="0" name="name" skips="0" tests="2" time="0.2">
  <testcase classname="classname" file="file" line="1" name="test_class" time="0.1"/>
  <testcase classname="" file="test" line="1" name="test_class" time="0.1"/>
</testsuite>
{noformat}
# Run the build and check the results

h3. Expected Results
Bamboo will show the two tests as expected in <Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-XXX/test and <Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-XXX/test/case/0 .

h3. Actual Results
The page <Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-XXX/test will not show the correct total number for tests:
 !Screen_Shot_2017-06-30_at_9_31_43_PM.png|thumbnail!

The page <Bamboo_URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-XXX/test/case/0 will show an unespected error:
 !Screen Shot 2017-06-30 at 9.22.14 PM.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: JUnit test results with a null classname are not correctly handled

fields.description:
h3. Summary
* With "Final Stage" enabled, stopping build causes build to hang

h3. Environment
* Bamboo v6.0.3
* Final Stage (_dark feature enabled_)

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# create a Project - Plan (_e.g. PROJ-PLAN_)
# enable Final Stage by running:
{noformat}
curl -u BAMBOO_ADMIN_USERNAME \
     -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
     -d '{"key":"bamboo.final.stages","enabled":true}' \
     -X PUT http://localhost:8085/rest/admin/latest/darkFeatures/bamboo.final.stages
{noformat}
_Reference:_ https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-9771

# create a Final Stage

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Bamboo doesn't automatically generate new MSBuild executables for versions 15 and newer.


h3. Environment
Windows.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Install MSBuild 15 
# Bamboo won't find the executable.

h3. Expected Results
Executable automatically created.

h3. Actual Results
Executable not there.
 
h3. Notes
[What's New in MSBuild 15|https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/msbuild/what-s-new-in-msbuild-15-0]

{quote}
Changed path
MSBuild is now installed in a folder under each version of Visual Studio. For example, C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2017\Enterprise\MSBuild.
{quote}

h3.Workaround
Add executable manually.
fields.summary: Bamboo doesn't find MSBuild 15 executable
"View as Bamboo Specs" - ArtifactDownloaderTask configuration uses a bad syntax

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
The metrics for failed test results are not clear and shown in a way that leads to confusion.

{panel}
There are three sources of information as for failed tests:
# Plan test summary: (<URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY)
#* The *Times broken* field here will tell you how many times a given test failed after being fixed.
# Job test summary: (<URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-JOB)
#* The *Times broken* field here will tell you how many builds were run with this test broken. Please notice that even if you don't make any change to fix the test this number will keep increasing after each build.
# Test details: (<URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY-JOB, then click the test)
#* The *Failures* field will count how many times Bamboo actually run this test and got it failed. It means that even if you don't have a new build and rerun the same one this number will increase in case your test still fail
{panel} 

The above was noticed after multiple tests.
There is no documentation about it and fields with the same name *Times broken* have different meanings which confuse users.

h3. Suggested Solution
# Change their values so they all show the same information. The Plan test summary(<URL>/browse/PLAN-KEY) could show the same information provided in the JOBs. This would make more sense to users when navigating between the JOB results and Plan results
OR
# Adjust the field names so they can better explain their content

Additionally, the *Failures* field could have the same meeting of those since this information including reruns don't seem to be very relevant.
fields.summary: Information about failed tests is confusing

fields.description:
h2. Summary
There is system property {{bamboo.stash.disable.build.status.updates}} which allows to disable build status updates for Bitbucket Server. If start Bamboo with this setting it will not send build complete status update, but continue to send inprogress build status.

h2. Expected result:
If {{bamboo.stash.disable.build.status.updates}}==true no build status notifications should be sent to Bitbucket Server
fields.summary: Can't disable build status notifications for Bitbucket Server

fields.description:
h3. Environment
* Bamboo 5.15.5
* User management (Windows Active Directory)
* Oracle Database

h3. Steps to Reproduce
* 100 users login at the same time
* a set of around 30 users (_same user but 30 different sessions_) perform same operation like create a plan/delete a plan where the input details are different for each users. 
* when 2-3 users login at every 1 min (_no issues observed_)
* when running above simultaneously (at least 5 to 6 users face internal server error)
fields.summary: Internal server error when multi login sessions performing actions

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Changing password through email reset password will have a Internal Server Error page if Crowd server does not permit the application to modify the user

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Configure Bamboo to use Crowd as user management
# Edit Crowd Server Application Permission so that Bamboo application does not have the permission to Modify user
# Setup Mail server in Bamboo
# Click on "Can’t access your account?" in the Login page
# Fill in the username (from Crowd server) to request password reset
# Access the link from Bamboo password reset email
# Fill in the new password to reset the password

Error message that the password can't be reset. It have to be done from the Crowd server side.

fields.summary: Better error handling when Crowd rejected password change

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When Bamboo queues a build, it sends an {{INPROGRESS}} notification to Bitbucket immediately. Because Bamboo may do this when no remote agents are available, this means that Bamboo could send {{INPROGRESS}} statuses for builds and never update them.

Instead, Bamboo should only be sending {{INPROGRESS}} once the build starts.


h3. Suggested Solution
Trigger {{INPROGRESS}} only when the build has actually commenced, or allow a configuration setting to control when {{INPROGRESS}} is sent to Bitbucket Server
fields.summary: Bamboo sends INPROGRESS state as soon as build is queued, not when build starts

fields.description:
h3. Summary
On the Test case result page, the test duration is calculated incorrectly

h3. Steps to Reproduce
{panel:borderColor=blue|borderWidth=2}(i) Reproduced using JUnit tests on Bamboo 5.15.5 and 6.0.3{panel}
# Run a Build with tests
# View the Test Results and Test Case Results pages

h3. Expected Results
Both values match

h3. Actual Results
The values do not match. 
* The Test result duration calculation starts with milliseconds 
* The Test case result duration calculation starts with seconds

h4. For example:
We ran JUnit tests in *MyPlan - MyBuild - MyJob -4*

In the JUnit test result XML file, the time for *MyJavaTest* is recorded as 1.204 seconds.

In the Test Results summary for this job, we see:
||Test||Duration||
|MyJavaTest| 1 sec|

In the test case result details for *MyJavaTest*, we see:
Duration: 20 mins

h4. Comparison:
Using the JUnit test value, 1.204:
{noformat}1.204 * 1000 = 1204
1204 / 60 = 20.066...
(0 d.p) 20.066 = 20{noformat}

h3.Workaround
There is no in-app workaround. 

That said, both values represent the same duration, just in different units.
To see the correct time, please perform the following calculation outside of Bamboo, to 0 decimal places, on the Test Case Result duration:
{noformat}Duration / 1000 {noformat}
fields.summary: Bamboo test case result detail page shows incorrect duration

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Bamboo 6.0.3 - opening any build which contains artifacts (S3 storage) takes longer time to load as compared to Bamboo 5.14.1.

Tested with same plan configurations in Bamboo 6.0.3 and Bamboo 5.14.1, below are the timings:
# Bamboo 6.0.3 - More than 1 minute
# Bamboo 5.14.1 - Less than 5 secs

Please note : Number of artifacts set for testing was - 10 artifacts (5 Shared and 5 Unshared). For artifacts size and list, see the attached file - {{bamboo-build-artifacts.png}}

# Configure a Bamboo plan with artifacts(shared, unshared both) stored in S3 bucket.
# After the build is successful, navigate to the plan build result > artifact tab

Data should load quickly within 5 sec.
